emphasis.docTitle: Catalogue of juvenile instars of oribatid mites ( Acari : Oribatida )—the next decade (2014–2023)

subSection.paragraph: ROY A. NORTON 1* & SERGEY G. ERMILOV 2

emphasis.docAuthorAffiliation: State University of New York , College of Environmental Science and Forestry, Syracuse, New York , USA .
Institute of Environmental and Agricultural Biology (X-BIO), Tyumen State University, Tyumen , Russia .

subSection.paragraph: � ermilovacari@yandex.ru; https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0913-131X

In its traditional, paraphyletic context (sans Astigmata ), oribatid mites comprise more than 11,000 known species ( Subías 2022 ). They are largely fungivores and decomposers in organic horizons of soil and have a plesiotypic ontogeny that includes four active, free-living juvenile instars. In a taxonomically organized 2014 catalogue, we summarized literature resources concerning the 805 species for which ontogenetic data (mainly morphological) were available. Herein, we supplement that catalogue with all data known to us that were published during the intervening decade. These relate to 267 species, of which 165 were described prior to 2014. As in the 2014 catalogue, representation is strongest among: the middle-derivative hyporder Nothrina; brachypyline superfamilies that are affiliated with aquatic, semiaquatic or intertidal environments ( Limnozetoidea , Ameronothroidea ); some eupheredermous groups ( Plateremaeoidea , Damaeoidea ); and Ceratozetoidea . Also as in 2014, groups that are underreprented, based on their high known diversity, are the ptyctimous Mixonomata ( Euphthiracaroidea , Phthiracaroidea) and the brachypyline superfamilies Oppioidea and Oripodoidea .
Key words: juvenile , immature oribatid mites , morphological development , ontogeny , soil fauna

A decade ago ( Norton & Ermilov 2014 ) we sought to increase attention paid to juveniles of the suborder Oribatida (in their traditional sense, sans Astigmata ) by highlighting the importance of immature mites in studies of morphology, soil ecology, life history and phylogeny. We then used the form of a catalogue to identify literature containing ontogenetic information about individual species. Data were available for only about 800 of the approximately 10,500 species then known, but these represented about 70% of known families.

Our purpose herein is to update the 2014 catalogue with data published during the intervening decade—no previously unpublished data are included. We also offer corrections and emendations to the original catalogue that take three forms: (1) a few previously overlooked data are added, included at the relevant position in the main listings; (2) some previously overlooked historical issues are noted; and (3) several specific errors are corrected.

The taxonomic organization follows that of the 2014 catalogue, with minor exceptions described in footnotes. If no new data have been published for a particular higher taxon, it is not mentioned. As in 2014, this is not a traditional taxonomic catalogue that lists all synonyms and combinations; for these, we refer the reader to Subías (2022) . Those synonyms or combinations necessary to locate the data in the cited papers are given in explanatory notes (N.B.). As in 2014, the author and date of a species name is not treated as a citation: the source of a name is included in the References only if it also contains cited data relating to juveniles.

As in 2014, our focus is the external morphology of the four active juvenile instars—larva, protonymph, deutonymph and tritonymph—and these data are considered primary (see below). Data considered secondary are those relating to biological topics such as feeding, culturing or development times; we included such data only if they relate to specific instars monitored in the laboratory and if the species is already included based on primary data. These criteria are met only rarely, so few secondary data are included herein; an unconstrained review of developmental data was recently presented by Pfingstl & Schatz (2021) . We did not include papers that relate only to internal anatomy. The period investigated starts in early 2014, when coverage of the 2014 catalogue ended, and runs through the end of 2023.

The abbreviations listed below indicate that the cited paper includes relevant information about the designated instar of the species in question. If an author published the same data in multiple papers, all are cited. However, we do not cite a different author’s repetition of such data unless there was some emendation or explanation.
Ds = description of body . The paper includes a verbal description of the instar that depicts the body or one or more major regions of it.

DsP = partial description of body . The paper describes only one or more particular body structures (e.g., gnathosoma, epimeral region, cornicles, specific leg segments). Figures of relevant details may be present but are not separately noted except in the case of gnathosoma and legs.
FB = figure(s) of body . The paper includes drawings or photographs that illustrate all or part of the body.

FEx = figure(s) of exuvia . The paper illustrates shed exuviae (full molts) or exuvial scalps. They are included only if other data on juveniles are present in the paper: figures restricted to exuvial scalps on an adult mite are not included.
FGn = figure(s) of gnathosoma . The paper includes full or partial images (separate drawings or photographs) of one or more gnathosomal components (subcapitulum, chelicera, palp).
FLg = figure(s) of legs . The paper includes images (separate drawings or photographs) of one or more legs, or substantial portions of them.

LSA = leg setation analysis . The paper analyses the setiform organs (setae, solenidia) on legs, identifying individual organs in text, figures or tables; a setal formula (below) is either given or derivable from the analysis. In some instances, the data were not given directly, but by referencing a different species that has been fully analysed: in such cases we indicate that data are ‘provided by comparison.’
LSF = leg setation formula . The paper provides simple counts of setiform organs on legs (usually as numerical formulae) but does not identify individual setae or solenidia.
DT = development time . The paper provides data on the duration of the instar under controlled laboratory conditions.
Cul = culturing . The paper provides information about maintaining the particular instar under controlled laboratory conditions.
Fd = feeding . The paper provides information about feeding behavior or food selection in the particular instar, under controlled laboratory conditions.

footnote.paragraph: 3 The oribatid mite family-group name Cepheidae (Cepheoidea) has been used for decades in an unambiguous concept, but it is a junior homonym. In 2014 we attempted to follow a then-current solution by applying the name Compactozetidae to this family and the name Eutegaeoidea to the superfamily that then included Compactozetidae and Eutegaeidae . This solution was unsatisfactory for several reasons, as explained by Halliday & Norton (2019) , whose request to remove homonomy by a change in spelling to Cepheusidae has been approved (International Commission on Zoological Nomenclature 2023 ). We tentatively retain the classification of Cepheusidae (as Cepheidae ) and Eutegaeidae used in 2014; Colloff (2023) proposed significant changes, but we had insufficient time to evaluate them.

subSection.paragraph:
1. Stoll (1891) illustrated a poronotic nymph (his Table 15 Fig. 3; ‘larva’ of
Oribata sp.
) and suggested it might be a juvenile of
Oribata rugifrons Stoll, 1891
. However, the latter species is a member of Galumnidae , designated the type species of
Kratzensteinia
by Oudemans (1919) . Stoll’s juvenile is a nymph of Brachypylina, not readily identifiable but clearly not a galumnid nymph.

2. Packard (1888 ; Plate 10, Fig. 8) illustrated an apparent nymph of Damaeidae with the larval scalp lost. It was tentatively associated (p. 42) with
Damaeus bulbipedata Packard, 1888
, from the same publication, but that is probably incorrect. The latter, considered a species inquirenda (
Marshall et al. 1987
), is likely a member of Oppiidae .

3. Banks (1895) suggested that
Hoplophora arctata Riley, 1874
is a juvenile (‘young’), but Riley’s illustrations clearly show it to be an adult mite, now generally interpreted as a synonym of
Acrotritia ardua (C.L. Koch, 1841) (
Marshall et al . 1987
)
. Banks also proposed (correctly) that
Hermannia trinebulosa Riley, 1885
—described in Hubbard (1885) —represented a juvenile (‘larval’) oribatid mite; the description is consistent with a nymph of Humerobatidae or trichoribatine Ceratozetidae .

4. Two macropyline oribatid mite species proposed by Hall (1911a , b) were based on juveniles of unknown members of Brachypylina:
Hoploderma capitata Hall, 1911
(a) and
Lohmannia spinosa Hall, 1911
(b). See Jacot (1930) ,
Marshall et al. (1987)
.

5.
Cymbaeramaeus pulvillifer Willmann, 1931
was knowingly based on a nymph; Grandjean (1932) quickly recognized the synonymy with
C. cymba (Nicolet, 1855)
.

6. Grandjean (1965) believed that the nymph attributed to
Tenuiala kurti Woolley & Higgins, 1955
was misidentified.

7.
Papillacarus vitis Elbadry & Nasr, 1977
was described and illustrated based on a single tritonymph, mistaken for an adult ( Elbadry & Nasr 1977 ).

8. Kumar (2004) discussed two species of purported fossil lice that
Dalgleish et al . (2006)
recognized as mites. The latter authors considered
Amblyceropsis indica
to be an ‘acariform mite, probably … Prostigmata’ but Kumar’s photograph (his Fig. 1A) clearly represents a larva of Lohmanniidae . They correctly identified
Anopluropsis khatamaensis
as an oribatid mite and in a subsequent erratum
Smith et al . (2007)
suggested it was a member of Nothroidea; Kumar’s photograph (his Fig. 1C) clearly shows an adult of Malaconothridae .

9. According to Colloff (2023) , the Australian mite shown by Walter (2004 ; his Fig. 11-2a) and considered a nymph of Cepheidae , is a nymph of
Porrhotegaeus sp.
, probably
P. ornatus J. Balogh & Mahunka, 1966
.

10. According to Colloff (2009), Łochyńska (2008c) misidentified a studied species as
C. dicella Colloff, 1990
. In personal communication with R.A.N. (2014) he suggested the following: ‘The most likely identity of the protonymph, deutonymph, and tritonymph is
C. tasmaniana
, which is the only Tasmanian
Crotonia species
with three pairs of c setae, clearly indicated in Łochyńska’s figures 35, 38 and 41.’

11. Łochyńska (2008b) studied the ontogeny of Tasmanian mites under the name
Crotonia ardala Luxton, 1987
, but this identification has been questioned by Colloff & Perdomo (2009) and Colloff (2010) .

12.
Kumar et al. (2011)
discussed Early Permian fossil mites from Himachal Pradesh , India , which they misidentified as members of the genus
Acarus
( Astigmata : Acaridae ). All photographs appear to represent juveniles of
Nothrus
( Nothridae ).

13. Elkawas (2011) proposed
Eobrachychthonius aegyptiacus Elkawas, 2011
, but this mite is not a member of Brachychthoniidae . It appears to be a deutonymph of Brachypylina, perhaps in Oripodoidea .

1. On p. 6 we mistakenly wrote ‘Michael (1884b) considered
Murcia ephippiata Koch, 1841a
possibly to be a nymph of
Fuscozetes fuscipes (Koch, 1844)
’. Michael (1884a, p 241–3) wrote of
Zetes ephippiatus Koch, 1836
, not
Murcia ephippiata
.
2. On pp. 12, 44, 50, 54, and 63, all citations of ‘Shereef 1971b’ should instead be Shereef 1973. In the reference on p. 129, ‘1971b’ should be replaced by 1973.

3. On p. 21 we incorrectly referenced Grandjean 1954b for data on
Parhypochthonius aphidinus
; the data instead relate to
Aphelacarus acarinus (Berlese, 1910)
and are included above under that species.

4. On p. 36, the data listings for
Novonothrus covarrubiasi
and
N. puyehue
should be reversed.

5. On p. 52, the author of
Tritegeus bisulcatus
was incorrectly given in parentheses. Also on p. 52, the name
Podopterotegaeus altimonticola
should be replaced by
Podopterotegaeus sp.

6. On p. 64, the authors of
Oppia denticulata
should be in parentheses.
7. On p. 98, in the Seniczak, S., Seniczak, A. & Kaczmarek (2014) reference, the phrase ‘in press’ should be replaced by ‘40, 449–462.’
8. On p. 106, Caloppidae should have been included in Table 2. Also, Eutegaeidae is misspelled.

Since the appearance of the 2014 catalogue, data concerning juveniles of 267 species of oribatid mites have been published and are referenced herein. Of these, 102 species were newly described during the intervening decade, including 17 species of macropyline taxa and 85 species of Brachypylina. It is encouraging that species long known only as adults have received considerable attention. Of the 165 previously known species listed above, many were described in classical works of A. Berlese, C.L. Koch, H. Nicolet, A.D. Michael, and other early authors; for these, we owe a large portion of the new data to the efforts of S. and A. Seniczak.

Among macropyline taxa, the Nothrina are well represented in the additions from the past decade, and ptyctimous Mixonomata remain poorly studied. Among Brachypylina—where association of adult and juvenile instars is compliated by a nearly metamorphic post-tritonymphal transformation—the diverse Oppioidea and especially Oripodoidea received relatively little attention. By contrast, Ceratozetoidea and those superfamilies that are mostly affiliated with aquatic, semiaquatic or intertidal environments, such as Ameronothroidea and Limnozetoidea , are well represented due largely to studies by V .M. Behan-Pelletier, T. Pfingstl, S. and A. Seniczak, and their colleagues. Eupheredermous brachypylines (e.g., Plateremaeoidea , Damaeoidea ) received much attention from the latter two authors, as well as from B. Bayartogtokh and the present authors. These several taxonomic patterns were evident in 2014 as well.

A goal of the 2014 catalogue was to increase attention paid to oribatid mite juveniles, but most effort still comes from a rather small group of authors, and progress has been only incremental. In 2014, there were 46 families of Brachypylina for which no ontogenetic data were available. 6 Considering the importance of juveniles—which have relatively conserved morphology—in morphological studies of phylogenetic relationships (e.g., Grandjean 1954a ), this number seems unacceptably high. Yet, in 10 years it has been reduced by only four: juveniles of Anderemaeidae , Caloppiidae , Eutegaeidae , and Plateremaeidae are now known.At the species level our rate of including ontogenetic data has not improved. In 2014, juveniles had been described for only about 8% of the roughly 10,500 species-group taxa then known (latter number from Subías 2014 ). In the past decade, juveniles were described for about 7% of the approximately 1,400 oribatid mite species or subspecies proposed. 7

While the rate of ontogenetic description has not increased, that is only one potential indicator of progress. Currently, we have no metric to assess how well the entire lfe cycle is being incorporated into studies of comparative morphology, phylogenetics or soil ecology.

7 The number 1,400 was derived from an unpublished, species-level database maintained by H. Schatz.
